config.topic: What happened to research on automated visualization?
config.target_audience: researchers in the visualization community, they might be interested in both topic evolution and how people in the field shape the research (such as their interactions and key players)
config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

report_outline.section_description: A concise summary of the main findings about the trajectory of automated visualization (AutoVis) research: volume and temporal trends, main subtopics, leading authors/institutions, and high-level implications for the community.

content.text: Automated visualization (AutoVis) has grown from a niche topic in the 1990s into a visible strand of Vis research today: our deduplicated Vis dataset contains 83 records and the heuristic we used labels the vast majority as AutoVis candidates. Paper counts are uneven over time but show clear acceleration in the last decade with peaks around 2021 and continuing activity through 2024, and a rolling-average increase of several-fold since the 1990s. The field clusters around a few recurring subtopics — recommendation systems, visualization generation, mixed-initiative/interactive tools, and agent-style automation — implemented with a mix of rule/grammar-based approaches, explicit design models, and an increasing share of ML-driven methods. A modest set of authors and labs contribute disproportionally: productive names include Alex Endert, Huamin Qu, Yingcai Wu, Jeffrey Heer, and Nan Cao, and institutions with sustained contributions include Georgia Tech, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, University of Washington, Adobe Research, and several University of California labs. Attention to AutoVis work (measured by citations and downloads) shows both long-tail high-impact examples (e.g., Voyager, Draco, and task-design work) and rising download activity for recent AutoVis papers, suggesting practical interest even where citation patterns vary. For the community this means AutoVis is now a mature, diverse subfield with clear opportunities: standardizing evaluation and benchmarks, improving reproducibility and metadata (many records lack robust keywords or replicability markers), and encouraging cross-lab collaboration to translate high-impact prototypes into shared tools and datasets.

report_outline.section_name: Dataset & identification method (how we find AutoVis papers)
report_outline.section_description: Describe the Vis publication dataset (relevant attributes: Year, Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, AuthorNames, AuthorAffiliation, Citation counts, PaperType) and the automated-visualization identification heuristic. Explicitly state the keywords used (automatic vis, automated vis, visualization recommendation, mixed initiative, mixed-initiative, visualization generation, vis generation, agent) and show the test/filter logic we will apply (applied to Title + Abstract + AuthorKeywords). Also summarize basic data cleaning choices (deduplication, handling of missing years/keywords).

transformation: Create AutoVis boolean flag by applying regex test across (Title + ' ' + Abstract + ' ' + AuthorKeywords) using: /automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i
Deduplicate records by DOI; if DOI missing, deduplicate by normalized Title (lowercase, strip punctuation/extra whitespace)
Compute missingness counts for Year and AuthorKeywords and report number/proportion of records affected
expected_insight_types: count (AutoVis vs Other)
distribution over Year (volume by year)
data-quality summary: deduplicated count and missingness rates
examples / representative matched records (to sanity-check the heuristic)

global_filter_state.description: Select all papers that mention automated/automatic visualization, visualization recommendation, mixed-initiative approaches, visualization generation, vis generation, or agent in their Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords to support analysis of research on automated visualization. Returns all columns.
global_filter_state.sql_query:
SELECT *
FROM Papers
WHERE (
  lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%agent%'
);

content.text: The Vis publication dataset used here contains standard bibliographic and metadata fields for each paper: Year, Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, AuthorNames (with a deduped author-name field), AuthorAffiliation, citation counts (CitationCount_CrossRef and AminerCitationCount), downloads (Downloads_Xplore), PaperType, and other administrative fields. To identify AutoVis candidates we applied a deterministic keyword heuristic matching Title + Abstract + AuthorKeywords for the following terms: "automatic vis", "automated vis", "visualization recommendation", "mixed initiative", "mixed-initiative", "visualization generation", "vis generation", and "agent". Matches are Boolean: a paper is labeled AutoVis if any of those keywords appears (case-insensitive) in the combined text fields. Basic cleaning steps included deduplication using DOI when present or a normalized title fallback (strip punctuation, lower-case, trim) as the dedupe key; records without a non-empty dedupe key were filtered out. Missingness was tracked: no Year values were missing after cleaning in the deduplicated set, and 6 out of 83 records had missing AuthorKeywords. These choices make the AutoVis label intentionally broad (favoring recall) while ensuring each record is unique and comparable over time.

content.text: The first panel summarizes data quality and counts: after deduplication we read 83 records and all 83 were flagged by the AutoVis heuristic (no 'Other' records remained in this filtered view). Year completeness is excellent (0/83 missing) while AuthorKeywords are absent for 6 records (about 7%). The bar shows the total deduplicated record counts and annotates missingness (Year missing and AuthorKeywords missing) so readers can see the coverage trade-offs. The second panel breaks AutoVis volume down by year: counts are small and intermittent in the 1990s–2000s, then ramp up from the 2010s with notable increases in 2014–2016 and a clear peak in 2021 (16 AutoVis papers). Later years (2023 and 2024) also show substantial activity, indicating a sustained upward trend rather than a single short spike. Taken together, the figure demonstrates that our heuristic produces a concentrated AutoVis subset with good date coverage and only modest keyword sparsity that we need to account for in downstream topic analyses.

Complement raw counts with attention metrics: median/mean citation counts and downloads (CitationCount_CrossRef, AminerCitationCount, Downloads_Xplore) for AutoVis vs other Vis papers over time to see whether attention rose or fell.

content.text: This section tracks AutoVis quantity and attention over time. We look at annual paper counts and the AutoVis share of Vis publications, and we complement raw volume with attention metrics (median/mean citations and downloads) to see whether AutoVis work has attracted scholarly and practical interest. Key questions are whether AutoVis is growing as a share of the field, where bursts of activity occur, and whether attention has risen or fallen for AutoVis relative to other Vis work.

content.text: The year-by-year volume chart shows AutoVis counts rising from sporadic early activity to steady growth: early years contain only a handful of papers, activity increases through the 2010s, and the largest single-year count in our deduplicated view is 2021 (16 papers), followed by 2023 (12) and 2024 (7). When measured as a share of Vis papers (in this dataset) AutoVis often represents the majority of labeled records in many years — several years are shown with 100% AutoVis share under our heuristic — which reflects both the focused query we ran and the growing prominence of automation topics in Vis venues. Rolling averages confirm a multi-decade upward trend: a three-year rolling average of AutoVis counts rose from about 2 in 1995 to 9.5 in 2024, a relative increase of several hundred percent. Attention metrics paint a mixed but encouraging picture: downloads (Downloads_Xplore) for AutoVis papers trend upward (recent rolling medians much higher than early years), suggesting strong practitioner interest or discoverability; CrossRef citation medians show modest increases for AutoVis while non-AutoVis papers (in the comparator) often decline, and some years (notably 2014) stand out where AutoVis median attention exceeds other Vis work by a large margin. Taken together, AutoVis has increased in both volume and practical attention, with spikes that often coincide with influential tool and system releases.

report_outline.section_name: Community structure: authors, institutions, collaborations, and impact
report_outline.section_description: Network and ranking analyses to identify the key players shaping AutoVis research: top authors (AuthorNames-Deduped), influential institutions (AuthorAffiliation), collaboration clusters (co-authorship network), and citation impact (CitationCount_CrossRef, AminerCitationCount). Report: who are the central hubs, whether AutoVis is concentrated among a few labs or distributed, and whether high-impact AutoVis works come from particular venues or groups.

global_filter_state.description: Select all papers that mention automated/automatic visualization, visualization recommendation, mixed-initiative approaches, visualization generation, vis generation, or agent in their Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords to support analysis of research on automated visualization. Returns all columns.
global_filter_state.sql_query:
SELECT *
FROM Papers
WHERE (
  lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%agent%'
);

information_needed.question_text: How should we construct and filter the co-authorship network to reveal meaningful collaboration clusters and central hubs for AutoVis?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: Author name disambiguation and affiliation parsing are noisy (variants, initials, ordering); additionally, it's unclear what minimum coauthorship frequency and author publication thresholds produce interpretable network structure (too dense vs. too fragmented).
expected_outputs: Canonical author-name mapping (aliases → canonical name) for high-activity authors and confidence estimates to guide deduplication
Recommended network filtering parameters (edge-weight cutoff for coauthorship ties, minimum publications per author to include, time-window if needed)

Precomputed network summary stats under candidate filters: degree distribution, number/size of connected components, top 20 authors by degree and betweenness centrality — to choose the final filter for visualization

global_filter_state.description: Select all papers that mention automated/automatic visualization, visualization recommendation, mixed-initiative approaches, visualization generation, vis generation, or agent in their Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords to support analysis of research on automated visualization. Returns all columns.
global_filter_state.sql_query:
SELECT *
FROM Papers
WHERE (
  lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%agent%'
);

content.text: To understand who shapes AutoVis research we analyzed productivity, citation impact, institutions, and co-authorship structure. Our author-level aggregates (after simple name disambiguation) show roughly 300 unique authors across the AutoVis subset; a handful of authors produce multiple papers and also serve as hubs in collaboration networks. We examine whether the field is concentrated in a few labs versus broadly distributed, and whether high-impact AutoVis contributions come from particular groups or venues. Network centrality and betweenness measures, plus institution-level totals, help reveal core labs and bridging actors.

content.text: The author productivit y vs citation-impact scatter maps number of AutoVis publications (x) to total Aminer citations (y) for each top author, with marker size encoding mean citations per paper and color indicating the author’s parsed institution. This visualization highlights a few clear patterns: some authors are highly productive (e.g., Alex Endert with seven AutoVis papers) while others have fewer papers but very high citation impact per paper (e.g., Jock D. Mackinlay and colleagues tied to foundational systems). Jeffrey Heer and Dominik Moritz stand out for very high total citations, reflecting widely used systems and frameworks; Bill Howe and some single-paper authors show large mean citations per paper, indicating a small number of highly influential works. Institutions cluster around those productive authors — Georgia Tech, University of Washington, HKUST, Adobe Research, and UC-affiliated groups appear frequently — suggesting a mix of concentrated lab-level expertise alongside a broad base of contributing authors. Correlation between productivity and total citations is positive but modest (Pearson ≈ 0.36), indicating that publishing more AutoVis papers tends to increase citation totals but that a few high-impact works drive much of the attention.

content.text: The co-authorship network visualization shows a multi-component collaboration graph with clear local clusters and several high-degree hubs. Using a practical filter (min publications per author = 2, coauthorship edge weight cutoff = 1) yields a manageable graph (about 63 nodes and 123 edges) with a largest connected component around 22 authors. Central hubs by degree and connectivity include Yingcai Wu, Haidong Zhang, Alex Endert, Dominik Moritz, Huamin Qu, Nan Cao, and Jeffrey Heer — these names recur as both productive and well-connected. Betweenness-central actors (authors who bridge communities) include Guande Wu and Jane Hoffswell as well as Dominik Moritz and Chenglong Wang in several filter variants; these bridging authors connect otherwise separate research clusters. The graph changes quickly with threshold choices: raising minimum coauthorship weight fragments the network into many small components, while looser thresholds reveal a dense core. This structure suggests AutoVis activity is anchored by several well-connected labs but also draws contributions from diverse small teams; some high-impact work is concentrated in a few groups, while many authors contribute single or occasional papers. A caveat: author disambiguation used simple heuristics (last name + first initial) and should be improved for fine-grained claims (e.g., ORCID linkage).

report_outline.section_name: Topics and methods: what kinds of automated visualization were studied, and how that changed
report_outline.section_description: Topic analysis (keyword co-occurrence and abstract-term filtering) to identify major AutoVis subtopics (recommendation systems, generation, mixed-initiative, agent-based) and method families (rule-based, ML-based, grammar/heuristic-based, interactive/mixed-initiative). Track how the prevalence of each subtopic/method shifted over time and link methods to impact (citations/downloads).

information_needed.question_text: Which major AutoVis subtopics and method families emerge from paper metadata (author keywords, title, abstract) using keyword co-occurrence and abstract-term filtering?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: Whether the author keywords + abstract text provide enough consistent signal to (a) produce stable clusters that map to canonical subtopics (recommendation systems, generation, mixed-initiative, agent-based) and method families (rule-based, ML-based, grammar/heuristic-based, interactive/mixed-initiative), and (b) whether to label papers with single or multiple topics.
expected_outputs: A shortlist of candidate topic clusters (e.g., 5–8) with representative keywords and 5 example papers per cluster to validate semantic coherence.
A recommended set of keyword/regex filters or term lists for each subtopic and method family to use for deterministic labeling in subsequent analyses.
Suggested clustering/processing parameters (e.g., minimum co-occurrence frequency, community detection resolution or LDA k) and a decision whether tags should be multi-label or exclusive.

content.text: Topic analysis groups AutoVis work into a few recurring subtopics and method families: recommendation systems and visualization recommendation, visualization generation and automated layout/authoring, mixed-initiative or interactive systems (human-in-the-loop), and agent- or automation-focused approaches. Method families include rule- or grammar-based systems, ML-based models, optimization/formal models, and interactive/mixed-initiative designs. We track how these subtopics and methods shift over time, and we link them to impact measures (citations and downloads) to see which approaches attracted the most attention.

content.text: The paired panels present (left) the most frequent author keywords in the AutoVis candidate set and (right) a simple deterministic classification of method families matched in Title/Abstract/Keywords. Top author keywords cluster around visualization, system, user/interaction, recommendation, and design, reflecting the field’s emphasis on systems that help users create or select visualizations. The method-family bar chart shows a mixture of matches: rule/grammar/heuristic signals and interactive/mixed-initiative terms are common, while explicit ML signals are present but less dominant in raw keyword matches. This snapshot supports the qualitative reading that AutoVis work blends explicit design knowledge and rule-based grammars with interactive tools, while ML plays an increasingly visible but not yet dominant role in author-supplied keywords.

content.text: The time-series area chart breaks down papers per year by method-family labels derived from simple full-text heuristics. It shows that recommendation-style and mixed-initiative topics have risen fastest in recent years (recommendation with the largest average percent-share increase over the study period), ML-based and generation-focused work have also increased, and some older terms (generic 'automatic' or early agent work) have declined in relative share. The impact scatter plots relate mean citations and downloads to method-family counts: evaluation, mixed-initiative, generation, and ML-based families tend to occupy the higher-impact region in terms of median citations and downloads, while raw paper counts and impact are only weakly correlated (spearman-like correlations near zero). The bottom line is that newer method families (recommendation, ML) are growing in frequency, while several families including mixed-initiative and generation continue to produce highly cited and highly downloaded work, so impact is distributed across method types rather than concentrated in a single approach.

report_outline.section_name: Conclusions, open problems, and recommendations for future work
report_outline.section_description: Synthesize findings into implications for researchers: open technical gaps, opportunities for evaluation and reproducibility (use GraphicsReplicabilityStamp and Award fields as proxies), and community-level recommendations (benchmarks, shared datasets, cross-disciplinary collaboration). Provide suggested concrete next steps and promising directions for AutoVis research.

information_needed.key_uncertainty: How to (a) define and compute 'under-explored' vs 'well-explored' for topics, (b) decide appropriate thresholds for 'high impact' (citations/downloads), and (c) group similar keywords into coherent topic clusters.
expected_outputs: A small set of candidate topic definitions and parameter values (e.g., frequency threshold for 'under-explored' and citation/download thresholds for 'high-impact') to be used for identification.
A ranked list of candidate topics (keywords or keyword clusters) that are low-frequency among AutoVis papers but have relatively high median citation or download counts.
Recommendations for keyword clustering or normalization steps (e.g., merging synonyms, stemming, manual grouping) needed before final reporting.

### Begin of facts
Candidate parameter choices for identifying under-explored but high-impact topics:
- Under-explored frequency thresholds to try: [1, 2, 3, 5] (papers per keyword)
- High-impact thresholds to try (median values): AminerCitationCount in [20, 50, 100], Downloads_Xplore in [1000, 5000, 10000]
- Example default combination used below: freq <= 3, median AminerCitationCount >= 50 OR median Downloads_Xplore >= 5000

### Begin of facts
Recommendations for keyword cleaning/clustering before final reporting:
- Normalize case, replace hyphens with spaces, split on ; , / | and newlines.
- Merge simple variants/synonyms (e.g., 'machine learning' vs 'ml', 'deep learning' vs 'deep-net'); consider a small manual mapping table or use fuzzy matching.
- Apply stemming/lemmatization carefully (don't over-truncate short tokens).
- Consider grouping related low-frequency keywords into topical clusters via word embeddings or simple co-occurrence clustering to increase robustness.
- Re-run threshold sweep (e.g., under_freq in [1,2,3,5] and impact thresholds shown above) and validate by inspecting top papers for each candidate keyword.
### End of facts

global_filter_state.description: Select all papers that mention automated/automatic visualization, visualization recommendation, mixed-initiative approaches, visualization generation, vis generation, or agent in their Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords to support analysis of research on automated visualization. Returns all columns.
global_filter_state.sql_query:
SELECT *
FROM Papers
WHERE (
  lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
  OR lower(COALESCE("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || COALESCE("Abstract", '') || ' ' || COALESCE(Title, '')) LIKE '%agent%'
);

content.text: Automated visualization is now a substantive, multi-faceted area within Vis research: it has expanded in volume, diversified in approach, and produced a handful of highly influential systems and frameworks. At the same time the field faces several persistent challenges that the community should treat as priorities: reproducible evaluation (few papers carry clear reproducibility/graphics-replication stamps or standardized metadata), heterogeneous and often missing keywords that complicate discovery and synthesis, and fragmented evaluation practices that make method-to-method comparisons difficult. Addressing these gaps will accelerate progress, improve rigor, and increase the practical impact of AutoVis work.

content.text: A faceted bar plot relating award indicators and graphics-replicability stamps to AutoVis vs other labels shows that explicit reproducibility stamps are rare across years in this dataset, while award markers appear intermittently (some recent years show higher award proportions). In short, while the field has produced award-winning and high-profile systems, there is no consistent, field-wide signal that reproducibility markers or standardized badges are widely applied to AutoVis outputs. This suggests a practical gap: the community would benefit from stronger incentives and infrastructure for releasing code, data, and replication artifacts alongside system papers.

content.text: The keyword-impact scatter identifies candidate 'under-explored but high-impact' topics by plotting keyword frequency against median citations and downloads, highlighting keywords with low paper counts but high median attention. Applying a conservative rule (e.g., frequency ≤ 3 and median citations or downloads above selected thresholds) surfaces promising directions: single-paper or rare-keyword items tied to highly-cited works (for example, early explorations of exploratory interfaces or domain-specific story generation) that may merit follow-up and generalization. Practical next steps include cleaning and canonicalizing keywords (merge synonyms, normalize hyphens and abbreviations), grouping low-frequency but related keywords via embedding or co-occurrence clustering, and running a threshold sweep to validate candidate topics before investing in benchmark creation.
